In the Drops: Shock Absorber Bra, ‘Great Rides According to G’ book and Halloween

Welcome back to another In the Drops! You’re seeing me slightly earlier in the schedule as the wonderful Emma is in Jordan. Before she left, she covered whether compression could help cyclists recover faster.

Elsewhere, I wrote about the Gravel World Championships, Tadej Pogačar winning Il Lombardia for the third year in a row and Thibaut Pinot retiring in my latest Pro Log. Of course, also the news of Mark Cavendish’s one-year deal with Astana. I interviewed Alix Popham too on how he’s using the bike to raise awareness of head trauma in sport.

Will covered all the tech at the Gravel World Champs and Joe wrote up his experience riding the gravel race of Unbound. If you’re into your bikes, there’s the news on the Canyon Grail and Cervélo Soloist Ultegra Di2 as well.

Right, into this edition of In the Drops…

Buyer’s guide: Best women’s cycling sports bras

Champion Shock Absorber Bra

I keep saying I want to be more active – whether that’s taking up tennis or even getting round to… [shudders] jogging – but the one thing that has stood in my way so far, apart from myself, is lack of a good sports bra.

This Ultimate Run Bra from Champion adds support with its double back fastening mechanism. Individual cup support is said to reduce bounce by 78% and I’ve found that for those with bigger chests, it’s definitely more compressive and supportive than my older sports bras.

The bra uses an Infinity-8 support system to do so, counteracting movement while running. The straps are wide and therefore non-slip (ideal for exercise) and I’ve found it hasn’t chafed either.

  • Buy now from Shock Absorber (£52)

‘Great Rides According to G’

Geraint Thomas is launching his fourth book in the ‘According to G’ series, following on from ‘The World of Cycling According to G’, ‘The Tour de France According to G’ and ‘Mountains According to G’.

His latest offering is a collection of ‘Great Rides’ features the 20 races, training rides and journeys ‘closest to Thomas’ heart’ across the world, including the white gravel roads of Tuscany and one-day cycles in the Peak District.

The book begins with a ride around his old Tuscan training base, where Thomas began his career as a GB Olympic hopeful. Along the way, he’s joined by ‘little b*stard’ (his frequent words, not mine) Remco Evenepoel in Calpe and Olympic mountain bike champion Tom Pidcock in Yorkshire.

Thomas’ character always shines through, whether it’s on paper or alongside Luke Rowe on their podcast. The book is a small-sized hardback, handy for packing on the train or taking to a local coffee shop where you can almost hear the Welsh accent in your mind.

  • Released 26th October

What we’re into this week: Halloween!

I love Halloween! I love Halloween! I love Halloween! I love Halloween! I love Halloween!

Now I’ve got my point across, there’s nothing that boosts my serotonin more than falling leaves, pumpkin spice lattes, hearty soups and getting in the spooky spirit. I’m always thinking about potential Halloween costumes, going to Farmaggedon and being scared, watching films like ‘Scream’ or ‘Pearl’ and decorating the flat with pumpkins and bats.

Lest I forget the annual pumpkin picking too (above), which is sort of a tradition for me.

See you next time!
